coredata.dc:title: In-situ forming flame-retardant gel polymer electrolyte through Ritter reaction: An innovative strategy for enhancing the safety of lithium metal battery

Zhou, Jian-Jun
Li, Lin
coredata.dc:description: Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) with higher energy-density have always been urgently needed. However, the safety risk and poor cycle performance are still great challenges for the widespread application of LMBs. Here, a flame retardant gel polymer electrolyte (FR-GPE) has been developed to address these problems. Copolymer containing phosphonate (PHAP) are synthesized through free radical polymerization and used as polymer matrix for gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) containing flame retardant. The PHAP is soluble in liquid electrolyte and can be cross-linked to gel liquid electrolyte through Ritter reaction. The advantage of this strategy is that cross-linking is initiated by LiPF6 without the need for additional initiator. The cross-linked PHAP GPE (c-PHAP-GPE) has excellent flame retardant and self-extinguishing properties. Moreover, it has high ionic conductivity, wide electrochemical stability window (5.11 V) and high Li+ transference number (0.74). The results show that the c-PHAP-GPE can improve the cycle performance of Li||NCM622 batteries by involving in the solid electrolyte interphase on both the Li anode and NCM622 cathode, promoting uniform Li deposition and suppressing the Li/Ni cation mixing. Our strategy of improving the cycle and safety performances of LMBs with in situ formed FR-GPE has paved a new way for developing advanced energy storage system.

(a) TGA profile of c-PHAP; (b) Images of ignition test for LE and c-PHAP-GPE.

(a) Ionic conductivity variation with temperature; (b) Linear sweep voltammetry curves of LE, c-PHA-GPE and c-PHAP-GPE; (c) Binding energy of Li+ with the functional groups; (d) LUMO and HOMO of the exponents in LE, PHAP and c-PHAP.

(a) Voltage profiles of Li||Li symmetric cells at 0.5 mA cm−2 and 1.0 mAh cm−2; (b) Enlarged voltage profiles; The surface morphology of Li electrode from (c) Li|LE|Li and (d) Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Li symmetric cells after 30 cycles.

head.ce:title: In-situ forming flame-retardant gel polymer electrolyte through Ritter reaction: An innovative strategy for enhancing the safety of lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: College of Chemistry, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875, China
ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: College of Chemistry, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875, China

ce:correspondence.ce:text: Corresponding author at: College of Chemistry, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875, China.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In-situ forming flame retardant gel polymer electrolyte to improve the cycle and safety performance of lithium metal batteries by promoting uniform Li deposition and suppressing the Li/Ni cation mixing.

Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) with higher energy-density have always been urgently needed. However, the safety risk and poor cycle performance are still great challenges for the widespread application of LMBs. Here, a flame retardant gel polymer electrolyte (FR-GPE) has been developed to address these problems. Copolymer containing phosphonate (PHAP) are synthesized through free radical polymerization and used as polymer matrix for gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) containing flame retardant. The PHAP is soluble in liquid electrolyte and can be cross-linked to gel liquid electrolyte through Ritter reaction. The advantage of this strategy is that cross-linking is initiated by LiPF6 without the need for additional initiator. The cross-linked PHAP GPE (c-PHAP-GPE) has excellent flame retardant and self-extinguishing properties. Moreover, it has high ionic conductivity, wide electrochemical stability window (5.11 V) and high Li+ transference number (0.74). The results show that the c-PHAP-GPE can improve the cycle performance of Li||NCM622 batteries by involving in the solid electrolyte interphase on both the Li anode and NCM622 cathode, promoting uniform Li deposition and suppressing the Li/Ni cation mixing. Our strategy of improving the cycle and safety performances of LMBs with in situ formed FR-GPE has paved a new way for developing advanced energy storage system.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: We have provided the data in the supporting information.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) has been widely used in portable electronics, electric vehicles, smart grids, etc [1,2]. However, potential safety risk of fire or exploration still exists in conventional LIBs since flammable liquid electrolytes (LEs) are used [3]. It is easy to catch fire or even explode in the event of thermal runaway due to large scale internal short circuit. This kind of safety issue is more prominent in pursuit of lithium metal batteries (LMBs) with higher energy–density, since the dendritic Li deposition on Li metal anode (LMA) will greatly increase the risk of short circuit [4]. The fundamental approach to address these obstacles is to substitute flammable LEs with solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) [5]. However, the application of SSEs in LMBs is still suffering from problems such as low ionic conductivity, poor interface compatibility with electrodes, etc [6].

Adding flame retardants (FRs) can make LE nonflammable and improve the safety of batteries. Numerous FRs have been investigated, such as trimethyl phosphate [7], triethyl phosphate [8] and dimethyl methylphosphonate [9], fluorinated phosphate ester [10], phosphonate containing PEG-based oligomer [11], ethoxy (pentafluoro) cyclotriphosphazene [12] etc. However, investigations on the flame retardant electrolyte show that FRs can involve in the interfacial reaction on both cathode and anode, and promote the formation of solid electrolyte interface film [12]. Since the FRs can enter the solvates of Li+, they will migrate with Li+ and lead to continuous interface reaction on the electrodes, which will sacrifice the capacity of the battery. Moreover, the risk of leakage is still not solved.

Gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs) are proved to be effective in preventing leakage and improving the interface compatibility with electrodes in LMBs [13,14]. GPE is composed of polymer matrix and LE components, which has the advantage of both SSEs and LEs [15]. The polymer matrix can hold the liquid exponents and make LE lose flowability, which will greatly decrease the risk of leakage and volatilization. At the same time, GPE can maintain relatively high ionic conductivity, suppress the decomposition of LE on the electrode interface and endue the battery with improved cycle performance. Therefore, flame retardant GPEs (FR-GPEs) have attracted great attention in recent years [13,16]. FR-GPEs can be prepared based on porous polymer matrix or in situ formed in the batteries [17]. Porous flame retardant membranes had been in situ plasticized with LE to become FR-GPE with high thermotolerance, excellent flame retardancy, satisfying ionic conductivity, large lithium-ion transference number, and good electrochemical stability. When inflammable highly-fluorinated carbonates is incorporated into LE to plasticize porous polymer matrix, the flame-retardant property of GPE can be improved [18]. Most studies were concentrated on precursor LEs containing monomer with P-moieties [19–21]. When they were polymerized or cross-linked in porous polymer matrix, the as formed free standing GPE membranes can enhance the safety and endow LMBs with high performance. However, preparing porous matrix will consume a large amount of solvent, which is not green and will bring extra emission of volatile organic compounds [22].

In situ forming GPE inside batteries can skip the step of preparing porous matrix in advance [23]. Monomers with FR moieties are dissolved in LE to prepare precursor LE, which is injected in the batteries and in situ polymerized and cross-linked to prepare FR-GPE. Vinyl and acrylic monomers, such as hexafluorobuty acrylate [24], vinyl imidazolium-based ionic liquid [25], spirocyclic pentaerythritol diphosphate perfluorinated ether acrylate [26], acryloyloxyethyl dialkyl phosphates [27], diethyl vinylphosphonate [28] etc. have been reported to prepare FR-GPE through free radical polymerization. It’s reported that the as formed fireproof GPEs can effectively suppress the deleterious reactions of the LE and impart nonflammable characteristics. However, the polymerization is usually initiated by free radical initiators. They are strong oxidants, which may bring parasite reactions on both the anode and cathode.

Li salts, as an essential part of LE and the source of Lewis acid, can initiate in situ reaction of monomers or polymers to prepare GPE [29]. Since no extra initiators are added, this strategy has aroused great interesting [30,31]. Recently, Song et al. [32] grafted fluoride containing moiety on to the chains of cyanoethyl poly-(vinyl alcohol) (PVA-CN) and prepared nonflammable GPE by cross-linking PVA-CN. However, hydroxyl groups in PVA-CN are unstable in the batteries when ternary cathode material containing high nickel is used. Herein, a copolymer containing hydroxyl, nitrile and diethyl phosphonate groups has been polymerized. The copolymer is dissolvable in LE and can be cross-linked in situ in the batteries to form non-flammable GPE. In the cross-linking process, the hydroxyl groups react with nitrile groups through Ritter reaction to form FR-GPE rich in nitrile and phosphonate groups. No residual hydroxyl groups exist in the as formed GPE, and superior cycle performance has been obtained in the LMBs using ternary cathode.

3-chloro-2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate (CHPMA), acrylonitrile (AN), diethyl vinyl phosphate (DEVP), azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN), dodecyl mercaptan, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) were purchased from Macklin. Ether type LE (1.0 M LiTFSI in 1,3-dioxolane/ ethylene glycol dimethyl ether = 1:1 (v/v)) with 1.0 wt% LiNO3) was purchased from Dodo Chem, China. Ester type liquid electrolyte (LE, 1.0 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate/ ethyl methyl Carbonate = 1:1 (v/v)) for LIBs with ternary cathode material (Item number: KLD-1230C) was purchased from Guangdong Canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd, China. Polyethylene (PE) separator (12 μm) was kindly supplied by SEMCORP, China.

Preparing binary copolymer and flame-retardant ternary copolymer: First, CHPMA and AN were added to a two-neck flask in a molar ratio of 2:3. Then, an equal volume of DMSO was added as a solvent. After that, 1 wt% of AIBN and 1 wt% of dodecyl mercaptan were added as an initiator and a chain transfer agent, respectively. Subsequently, the solution was bubbled with nitrogen for 25 min, and then heated to 75 °C for a reaction time of 8 h. After reaction, the solution was precipitated in ethyl acetate and centrifugally separated and washed with ethyl acetate for three times. The product was vacuum dried at 60 °C to obtain the copolymer of CHPMA and AN, named PHA. For the ternary copolymer, CHPMA, AN and DEVP were added in a molar ratio of 2:3:5. The same procedure was adopted to synthesize the ternary copolymer of CHPMA, AN and DEVP, named PHAP.

Preparing homopolymer of DEVP: DEVP was dissolved in DMSO with a concentration of 15 wt%, which was added into a two-neck flask. The solution was bubbled with nitrogen for 25 min and then heated to 75 °C, followed with1 wt% AIBN as an initiator. The reaction was lasted for 24 h, and then the solution was precipitated with ethyl acetate. After centrifugally separated and washed three times, and dried at 60 °C, homopolymer of DEVP was obtained, named PDEVP.

Preparing GPE: PHA or PHAP was weighed and placed into a 5 mL transparent reagent bottle. LE was added to dissolve the copolymer and obtain a transparent precursor solution, named PHA-LE or PHAP-LE. Both ether type LE and ester type LE were used. The ether type LE was used in Li||Cu batteries, and the ester type LE was used in stainless steel (SS)||SS, Li||Li, Li||SS and Li||NCM622 batteries. The precursor solution was heated at 55 °C for 24 h to initiate the Ritter reaction. Gel polymer electrolyte was obtained, named as c-PHA-GPE or c-PHAP-GPE, respectively.

Preparing LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 (NCM622) cathode: NCM622, conductive graphite, acetylene black and PVDF were mixed in a mass ratio of 8.5:0.5:0.5:0.5, in which PVDF was added in NMP solution with the concentration of 5 wt%. The mixture was grinded with appropriate NMP to homogenize the slurry. NCM622 cathode was obtained by coating the slurry onto a carbon-coated aluminum foil and dried. The mass load of NCM622 was approximately 4.5 mg cm−2. The NCM622 cathode was punched into disks with the diameter of 10 mm.

The structure was characterized by 1H NMR (JNM-ECZ600R). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) (Bruker VERTEX 70) was used to study functional groups of the copolymers at 400–4000 cm−1. The thermal stability was studied using a thermal analysis instrument (STA449 F5) in the temperature range of 50–650 °C under a N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The morphology was characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, SU-8010, Hitachi). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis was conducted using an ESCALAB 250 Xi analyzer integrated with monochromic AlKα (1486.6 eV) X-ray beam radiation (15 kV and 20 mA) and binding energy is calibrated vs. carbon (C1s = 284.6 eV).

CR2032 coin cells were assembled to evaluate the FR-GPE. Li||NCM622 batteries were assembled with the following procedures. In a positive battery shell, NCM622 cathode (Ф = 10 mm, ∼4.5 mg cm−2), 15 μL ester type LE or precursor LE (5 wt% PHA or PHAP dissolved in ester type LE), a piece of PE separator (Ф = 19.5 mm), another 15 μL LE or precursor LE, Li foil (Ф = 15.6 mm), SS plate, spring plate and the negative battery shell were put on sequentially and sealed. For the batteries filled with precursor LE, they were heated at 55 °C for 24 h to prepare Li|c-PHA-GPE|NCM622 and Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 batteries with the in situ formed GPE. Li||Li, SS||SS and Li||SS batteries were also prepared using ester type LE with the same procedures. Li||Cu batteries were assembled with similar procedures, except that ether type LE was used.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was measured using an electrochemical workstation (Interface 1010E, Gamry) at 25 °C and within a frequency range of 106-10-1 Hz. The ionic conductivity was calculated using the resistance from SS||SS batteries according to the equation σ = L/(R × S), where L is the thickness of GPE, R is the resistance, and S is the contact area. The Li+ transference number (
t
Li
+
) in Li||Li symmetric cells was determined using chronoamperometry with a DC pulse of 10 mV and EIS tests at 25 °C. The electrochemical stability window was characterized by the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) of Li||SS batteries at 25 °C, with a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s−1. Li||Li symmetric cells were cycled at 0.5 or 1.0 mA cm−2 and 1.0 mAh cm−2. The assembled cells were tested on a battery testing system (CT2001A LANHE). The Li||NCM622 batteries were tested within a voltage range of 2.8–4.3 V at 25 °C.

Density functional theory (DFT) was employed to optimize the structures and calculate the binding energies, using the B3LYP functional method and the 6–31 + G(d, p) basis set. All calculations were performed using the Gaussian 16 program package. The binding energy (Eb) of substances A and B was calculated using the following Eq. (1).
(1)
E b
=
E
A / B
-
E A
-
E B
where EA/B is the energy of the interaction system of A and B, and EA and EB are the energies of A and B, respectively.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesizing and characterizing copolymers for GPE
ce:section.ce:para: Hydroxyl and nitrile groups functionalized binary copolymers (PHA) were synthesized with CHPMA and AN as monomers by free radical polymerization (Fig. 1 a). To endow the copolymer with flame retardant properties, phosphonate groups were further introduced to prepare ternary copolymers (PHAP) (Fig. 1b). The copolymers were characterized with 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra. In Fig. 1(c) and Table S1, the chemical shift of 5.47 ppm (g) corresponds to the H on the –OH in CHPMA, the chemical shift of 2.54 ppm (b) is assigned to the H on the carbon connected to –CN in AN. The H on CHPMA and AN can be seen in the 1H NMR spectra, which can suggest the successfully synthesis of PHA. Beside the H on PHA, the chemical shift of 1.26 ppm (i) is observed, which can be attributed to the H on the –CH3 at both ends of the phosphonate group in DEVP. The results can corroborate the preparation of PHAP. To determine the specific ratio of different components in the copolymer, PHA and PHAP were further analyzed by 13C NMR as showed in Fig. 1d and Table S2. The chemical shift of 175.39 ppm (h) corresponds to the C on the ester group in CHPMA, and the chemical shift of 121.47 ppm (b) corresponds to the C on the –CN in AN. According to the area ratio, the molar ratio of CHPMA to AN is 1:1.28 in PHA binary copolymer (Table S3). The chemical shift of 16.80 ppm (l) corresponds to the C on the methyl group of the phosphonate in DEVP. The molar ratio of CHPMA, AN and DEVP in the PHAP ternary copolymer is 1:1.34:1.16. The molar ratio of CHPMA and AN units is close to the feeding ratio, while there is an obvious deviation of DEVP feeding ratio with the molar ratio. This is due to the reaction properties of DEVP. The radicals of vinyl phosphate are prone to transfer from the C to P, which will lead to the termination of chain propagation [33]. The molecular weight of PHA and PHAP was characterized by gel permeation chromatography (GPC) with polystyrene as a standard sample. The number-average molecular weight (Mn) of PHA is 18.6 × 104, and the weight-average molecular weight (Mw) is 38.5 × 104, with a polydispersity index (PDI) of 2.1 (Table S4). The Mn and Mw of PHAP are 10.7 × 104 and 20.6 × 104, with a PDI value of 1.9.

Both PHA and PHAP are dissolvable in LE. When the concentration of PHA and PHAP in LE are higher than 3 wt%, the precursor LEs turn into GPEs (c-PHA-GPE, c-PHAP-GPE) with obviously increased viscosity after heated at 55 °C for 24 h (Fig. 2 and Fig. S1). As the concentration is higher than 5 wt%, the transparent precursor LEs become non-flowable GPE. When heated, LiPF6 in LE will decompose to produce trace amount of PF5, a strong Lewis acid, which can initiate the Ritter reaction between hydroxyl and nitrile groups in PHA or PHAP [31,34,35]. The polymer chain segments can be cross-linked with amide group to form three-dimensional network as illustrated by Scheme S1.

To ascertain the Ritter reaction among PHAP chain segments, the cross-linked PHAP (c-PHAP), purified from the GPE, was characterized with Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), as shown in Fig. 2b. The band at 1630 cm−1 corresponds to the stretching vibration of −C = C in the monomers, which disappears in the polymers, indicating the polymerization of the monomers. The bands at 1725 and 3480 cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of the −C = O and –OH in the CHPMA monomer, which are observed in PHA and PHAP, suggesting the successfully incorporating CHPMA repeating unit in the copolymers. The band at 2240 cm−1 corresponds to the –CN in the AN monomer, which can be observed in the polymers, verifying the incorporation of AN repeating unit in the copolymers. Furthermore, characteristic bands at 1220 cm−1, and 1023 and 1049 cm−1 appear in DEVP, HAP and c-PHAP, which can be attributed to −P = O and −PO- of phosphate, manifesting the successful integration of DEVP repeating unit in HAP. In the profile of c-PHAP, the band intensity at 2240 and 3480 cm−1 decreases, while a new band at 3360 cm−1 arises, which can be assigned to –NH of amide group. The band intensity decrease of –OH and –CN and the emergence of –NH corroborate the formation of amide group by Ritter reaction [31,34].

The thermal stability of c-PHAP and c-PHA was measured with thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under nitrogen. The temperature at 5 wt% weight loss is taken as the initial decomposition temperature. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the decomposition temperatures of c-PHAP and c-PHA are 271.1 and 263.3 °C, respectively. Both polymer matrices show high thermal stability. The residual mass of c-PHAP is about 24.65 %, higher than that of c-PHA (2.21 %) at 650 °C, which suggests that the phosphate group can endow c-PHAP with excellent flame retard property. In the ignition test, it is verified that the c-PHAP-GPE infiltrated nonwoven fabric has excellent flame retardant property (Fig. 3b and Movie S1 in Supporting information). When it was removed from the fire source, the flame quickly extinguishes, showing superior self-extinguishing property. The flame retardancy and self-extinguishing properties of c-PHAP-GPE should be of great significance to the safety of high energy density LIBs. On the contrast, LE soaked nonwoven fabric deflagrates and burns out within 5 s (Fig. 3b and Movie S2 in Supporting information). The comparison can ascertain the role of c-PHAP-GPE in improving the safety performance of LIBs.

The ionic conductivities were characterized by EIS as showed in Fig. 4 a. At 25 °C, the ionic conductivity of LE is 6.67 mS cm−1. After the precursor LEs (with 5 wt% PHA or PHAP) become GPE, the ionic conductivities of c-PHA-GPE and c-PHAP-GPE are 1.53 and 1.91 mS cm−1, respectively. As the temperature rises, the ionic motion accelerates, and the ionic conductivity increases correspondingly. The ionic conductivity can be linearly fitted against 1/T using Arrhenius equation. The activation energies for LE, c-PHA-GPE and c-PHAP-GPE were 0.122, 0.151 and 0.134 eV, respectively. The activation energy of GPE is larger than that of LE, which means that slightly higher energy barrier is needed for Li+ transport in GPE.

The electrochemical stability window was tested with linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). As showed in Fig. 4b, the decomposition voltage of c-PHAP-GPE (5.11 V) and c-PHA-GPE (4.82 V) is much higher than that of LE (4.37 V). The improved decomposition voltage suggests that GPE can extend the electrochemical stability window. In GPE, the polymer matrix can bind the solvents in LE, which can inhibit their decomposition on the electrode [36]. Furthermore, the residual –CN on the polymer matrix have strong electron-withdrawing ability, which can also contribute to resisting oxidation and improve the electrochemical stability window of c-PHAP-GPE or c-PHA-GPE. Therefore, it is reasonable to see that the electrochemical stability window of c-PHAP-GPE or c-PHA-GPE is higher than that of LE. The Li+ transference number (
t
Li
+
) was calculated by electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) and chronoamperometry as shown in Fig. S2. The
t
Li
+
of c-PHAP-GPE is 0.74, much higher than that of LE (0.39) and c-PHA-GPE (0.52), which can be attributed to the interaction of Li+ with phosphonate, nitrile, amide and ester groups on the polymer matrix. The interaction may have facilitated the transport of Li+ by modifying the solvate structure of Li+. Moreover, the non-flowable GPE can slow down the migration of anion due to much higher viscosity. Both factors may lead to higher
t
Li
+
in GPE. A higher
t
Li
+
is beneficial for decreasing the interfacial polarization of anions and suppressing the decomposition of Li salts on the anode, which should be of great significance for stabilizing the solid electrolyte interface of anode and improving the cycle stability of the battery [37]. Since the c-PHAP-GPE has better electrochemical performance, DFT was used to give more insight.

DFT was first used to calculate the binding energy (Ea ) between the functional groups on the polymer matrix and Li+ (Fig. 4c). The Ea of the nitrile, ester, amide and phosphonate groups with Li+ is −1.52, −1.78, −1.95 and −2.14 eV, respectively. The lowest Ea suggests that it is the easiest for phosphonate group to associate with Li+. In the optimized structure of c-PHAP and Li+ system, Li+ tends to associate with P = O as circled in Fig. S3. Therefore, the phosphonate group in c-PHAP will promote the dissociation of Li salts, which might be the reason for the higher ionic conductivity of c-PHAP-GPE than c-PHA-GPE.

The lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy levels of PHAP, c-PHAP and the components in LE were further calculated with DFT as showed in Fig. 4d. It can be observed that LiPF6 has the lowest LUMO (−1.58 eV). The frontier orbitals of LiPF6 lie in the Li+, indicating the first reduction of Li+. Except LiPF6, the c-PHAP has the second lowest LUMO (−1.00 eV). It suggests that compared to the solvent exponents in LE, it is more easily reduced. Therefore, it is supposed that c-PHAP should get involved in the SEI film on the Li electrode surface [38,39]. In the cells using LE, the SEI film on the Li anode surface mainly consists of oligomer or organic compounds with small molecular weight produced by reducing the solvent exponents, which is fragile and easy to decompose [40]. When c-PHAP-GPE is used, the c-PHAP involved SEI film should be tougher since the cross-linked polymer matrix has infinite molecular weight, which should be helpful for stabilizing the interface of Li anode and suppressing the continuous decomposition of liquid exponents. On the other side, the c-PHAP has the highest HOMO (−7.27 eV), which means it is the exponent to be firstly oxidized on the cathode side. The nitrile and amide groups on c-PHAP can coordinate with the transition metal ions in the cathode [31,41], which is beneficial for the adhesion of c-PHAP on the cathode surface. The oxidization of c-PHAP may promote the growth of solid electrolyte interface layer with infinite molecular weight on the cathode (CEI), suppressing the dissolve of transition metal ion and stabilizing the structure of cathode surface [42,43]. Therefore, it is expected that the c-PHAP-GPE can improve the battery performance by stabilizing the structure of both Li anode and ternary cathode.

Li||Li symmetric cells were assembled to study the effect of c-PHAP-GPE and c-PHA-GPE on Li deposition and stripping behavior. It’s observed that obvious overpotential hysteresis occurs in the Li|LE|Li cells after about 300 h at 0.5 mA cm−2 and 1.0 mAh cm−2, while the Li deposition/stripping overpotential is stable in the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Li and Li|c-PHA-GPE|Li cells after 800 h (Fig. 5 a). As the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Li cell is cycled at 2.0 and 2.5 mA cm−2, the initial large overpotential can decrease obviously with cycle numbers (Fig. S4), which may benefit from the high
t
Li
+
of c-PHAP-GPE. As the current density is returned to 0.5 mA cm−2, the overpotential of Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Li cell is 43.2 mV, smaller than that of Li|LE|Li cell (80.5 mV). The results demonstrate that GPE is effective in promoting uniform Li deposition and mitigating the polarization. The overpotential profiles are square waves with the magnitude of 50 mV in the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Li cell when long term cycling at 0.5 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5b), which suggests that the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer should be stable on the Li electrode surface. The surface morphology was studied with SEM. As showed in Fig. 5c, loose overgrowth Li dendrites are observed on the Li electrode from the Li|LE|Li cell. In a sharp contrast, Li is uniformly deposited in large grain size on the Li electrode from Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Li cell (Fig. 5d). The large grain size Li deposition has much smaller specific surface area, which can greatly reduce the parasite reactions with LE, contributing to forming more stable SEI layer on its surface [44]. Stable interface layer and dendrite-free Li deposition are beneficial for improving the cycle performance of Li anode in LMBs. Li||Cu batteries were assembled to evaluate the effect of c-PHAP-GPE and c-PHA-GPE on the Coloumbic efficiency (CE) of Li deposition/stripping. It can be observed that the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Cu and Li|c-PHA-GPE|Cu batteries can be stably run for more than 200 cycles with a CE of ∼ 98.5 % (Fig. S5a). While the CE of Li|LE|Cu battery dives after 118 cycles. Larger polarization exists in the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Cu and Li|c-PHA-GPE|Cu batteries initially (Fig. S5b). After 100 cycles, the polarization is comparable in the three types of Li||Cu batteries (Fig. S5c). However, the polarization is less in both the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Cu and Li|c-PHA-GPE|Cu batteries after 150 cycles (Fig. S5d), which suggest that less parasite reaction has taken place on the electrode surfaces, confirming that GPE can promote the formation of more stable solid electrolyte interface. These results agree well with those obtained from Li||Li symmetric cells.

XPS was used to characterize the valence states of elements on the Li electrode surface. There are mainly C, O, Li, F and P elements in the XPS survey spectra (Fig. S6). The peak position is corrected with the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. The peaks at 399.4 eV in the N 1 s and 286.3 eV in the C 1 s match well with the −C≡N, and the peaks at 399.8 eV in the N 1 s and 288.8 eV in the C 1 s spectra can be assigned to –NH-C = O (Fig. 6 a) [31,45]. The coexistence of −C≡N and –NH-C = O can verify that the c-PHAP-GPE involves in the SEI film formation. The c-PHAP involved SEI film can inhibit the continuous corrosion of LE and stabilize the Li anode interface. The peaks at 289.8 eV in the C 1 s, 531.5 eV in the O 1 s and 54.3 eV in the Li 1 s spectra match well with Li2CO3. Li2CO3, an inherent component of the SEI film, originates from the decomposition of ester solvents [46]. The ratio of Li2CO3 on the Li electrode from Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Li cells is much lower than that from Li|LE|Li cells (Fig. 6b), suggesting that LE decomposition has been suppressed due to using c-PHAP-GPE. The peaks at 56.4 eV in the Li 1 s and 685.0 eV in the F 1 s spectra can be attributed to LiF. The peaks at 686.9 eV in the F 1 s and 134.9 eV in the P 2p spectra are the characteristic peaks of LixPOyFz, while the peaks at 687.6 eV in the F 1 s and 136.9 eV in the P 2p are assigned to LixPFy. In the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Li cells, the ratio of LiF and LixPOyFz is much higher than that of LixPFy, while it is the opposite in the Li|LE|Li cells. LixPFy is considered as the main decomposition product of LiPF6 through electron reduction, and LiF can block the contact between the electron and LiPF6 [47,48]. Higher ratio of LiF and LixPOyFz on the Li electrode from the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|Li cells suggests that the decomposition of LiPF6 is suppressed. The peaks at 398.7 eV in the N 1 s and 55.2 eV in the Li 1 s spectra can manifest the formation of Li3N (Fig. 6a). Li3N is lithiophilic and has high ionic conductivity for Li+, which can homogenize the Li+ flux, reduce the nucleation overpotential and promote uniform lithium deposition [49]. This is consistent with the large grain size Li deposition observed in Fig. 5(d).

Li||NCM622 batteries were assembled to evaluate c-PHAP-GPE and c-PHA-GPE with high voltage cathode material. The initial capacity of Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 and Li|c-PHA-GPE|NCM622 batteries is slightly lower than that of Li|LE|NCM622 battery (Fig. 7 a). From the charge–discharge curves, it can be observed that although larger initial polarization exists in the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 and Li|c-PHA-GPE|NCM622 batteries, it increases in a much slower rate than that in the Li|LE|NCM622 battery (Fig. 7b-c and Fig. S7). After 500cycles, the capacity of Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 and Li|c-PHA-GPE|NCM622 battery is 132.2 and 106.7 mAh g−1, respectively. The capacity retention reaches 81.9 % and 76.3 %, much higher than that of Li|LE|NCM622 battery (23.43 %). The capacity of Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 battery decays in a constant rate of 0.020 mAh g−1 per cycle for more than 900cycles, while the capacity of Li|LE|NCM622 battery dives after 383 cycles. It’s well accepted that capacity diving is due to sharp increase in internal resistance, which may be caused by the exhaustion of LE or depletion of Li anode [50]. Here, Li foil with the thickness of about 550 μm was used, the capacity of which is far excessive. Therefore, it is supposed that the capacity diving is mainly originated from the excessive consumption of LE on the Li metal anode, resulting in LE exhaustion and sharp increase in internal resistance. The surface morphology of Li anode from the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 battery was observed with SEM (Fig. S8). It can be seen that dense Li deposition with large grain size can still be observed after 71cycles, which confirms that the c-PHAP-GPE can suppress the proliferation of Li dendrites. The Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 battery can discharge much higher capacities at 1.0 and 2.0C (Fig. 7d). As the C-rate is recovered to 0.1C, this trend can still be kept, which means better reaction dynamics and reversibility than the Li|c-PHA-GPE|NCM622 and Li|LE|NCM622 battery. The stable cycle performance of Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 battery can further support that c-PHAP-GPE can stabilize Li metal anode and retard the consumption of LE.

XPS was used to characterize valence states of elements on the NCM622 cathode surface. Similar to those on the Li anode surface (Fig. 6a), −C≡N and –NH-C = O are also observed on the NCM622 cathode from Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 battery (Fig. 8 a), indicating that the c-PHAP matrix has also involved the formation of solid electrolyte interphase layer on the cathode (CEI). The ratio of Li2CO3, a component from decomposed ester solvents in LE, is significantly lower on the cathode from Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 battery than that from Li|LE|NCM622 battery (Fig. 8b), suggesting that the c-PHAP involved CEI film can inhibit the decomposition of ester solvents. In the Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 battery, the ratio of LixPFy is much less than LiF and LixPOyFz, indicating that less LiPF6 is decomposed on the NCM622 cathode. In the Ni 2p spectrum, the peaks at 853.6 eV and 861.4 eV can be assigned to Ni2+, and the peak at 855.3 and 864.2 eV can be attributed to Ni3+, respectively [51]. The ratio of Ni2+/Ni3+ is an indication of the Li/Ni cation mixing [52]. The normalized peak areas of Ni2+ are 0.712 and 0.720 for the cathode from Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 and Li|LE|NCM622 batteries, corresponding to the Ni2+/Ni3+ ratio of 2.47 and 2.57, respectively. Lower Ni2+ ratio on the cathode from Li|c-PHAP-GPE|NCM622 battery suggests that the Li/Ni cation mixing can be suppressed with the c-PHAP-GPE. It’s reported that the nitrile and amide groups can associate with transition metal to suppress their dissolution as well as the Li/Ni cation mixing [41,53]. Therefore, it is supposed that the nitrile and amide groups on c-PHAP matrix can associate with Ni3+ and suppress the Li/Ni cation mixing, facilitating the structural stability of NCM622 cathode.

Flame retardant PHAP was synthesized through free radical polymerization. PHAP is soluble in liquid electrolyte, and can gel liquid electrolyte through Ritter reaction. The c-PHAP-GPE not only has excellent flame retardant and self-extinguishing properties, but also shows high ionic conductivity, wide electrochemical stability window and high Li+ transference number. DFT calculation results demonstrate that the P = O on the phosphate group can associate with Li + and promote the dissociation of Li salts. The results of Li||Li symmetric cells show that the c-PHAP-GPE can contribute to constructing a stable SEI film on the Li metal anode and promoting dendrite-free Li deposition. In the Li||NCM622 batteries, the c-PHAP-GPE can improve the cycle performance of Li||NCM622 batteries by stabilizing the NCM622 cathode structure and suppressing the Li/Ni cation mixing. We hope that the strategies of in-situ forming FR-GPE by cross-linking phosphate containing polymer will provide inspiration for designing advanced LMBs with improved cycle and safety performance.

Si-Xin Jia: Writing – original draft, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation. Tian-Qi Xiang: Investigation, Data curation. Zi-Han Zhang: Data curation. Jian-Jun Zhou: Writing – review & editing, Project administration, Funding acquisition. Lin Li: Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Conceptualization.
